resources.string: In general, security is the quality or state of being secure—to be free from danger. In other words, protection against adversaries—from those who would do harm, intentionally or otherwise—is the objective.

Malware known as Trojan SMSs worm is a major type of malicious app used to interrupt the normal operations of your mobile device and gain access to the private information you have stored in it such as address book. These kinds of threats are called Malware. Some examples of what they do are: steal your contacts and pictures, track your location, access your text messages, log your keystrokes and passwords, Send SMS messages to premium numbers without your knowledge that can result in a very high phone bill, fake legitimate banking applications and steal your personal banking information when you log in. Trojan-SMS Agent is currently ranked 210 in the world for mobile, online and PC malware, affecting between 50,000 and 100,000 users. Unfortunately, today SMS Trojans are one the easiest ways for cybercriminals to make easy money fast. Malicious use of premium rate SMS services is spreading around the world.

That morning Melissa didn't feel like going to work. During her previous week she had had too much work to keep up with now that her boss was out on vacations, and the sore throat that threatened to develop into a cold convinced her that staying home was the right thing to do. \‘Poor Debbie\’ she thought. \‘I hope she can handle all my customers today\’.
After calling out from work, she realized that she didn't even have the intention to get out from under her sheets, until her body came up with physiological excuse to do so, which didn't take too long. –Ugh… hate my life—she said, while washing her face on the bathroom sink. Suddenly the annoying but familiar sound of her alarm went off and she debated whether to keep listening to it or just going back to her bedroom and turning it off. She opted for the latter. After turning it off, she took her phone from her drawer and took it to the bathroom with her to read her newsfeed on Facebook while she brushed her teeth with the other hand.
However before opening her Facebook app, she noticed 6 SMS text notifications from her friend Debbie. –Oh my god, is she freaking out already!? —She mumbled still with her toothbrush in her mouth. She went ahead and opened one of the text messages.
‘You’ll not believe this! Check this out: http://bitk.it/1cnQkZU’ —said the text message. Melissa\’s curiosity made her click on the text message and her browser opened tons of websites with advertisements of every kind.
Not understanding why Debbie would send her a link like that, she decided to call her in case she had missed the point. But after opening her contacts app, she noticed that all her contacts were all gone and the next week she got her bill with an additional $104.59 for text messages to international numbers.

Cloud computing is a phrase used to describe a variety of computing concepts that involve a large number of computers connected through a real-time communication network such as the Internet. It is very similar to the concept of utility computing. In science, cloud computing is a synonym for distributed computing over a network, and means the ability to run a program or application on many connected computers at the same time.
 There are mainly four models of cloud computing: 
 1. Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS).
 2. Platform as a Service (PaaS).
 3. Software as a Service (SaaS).
 4. Network as a Service (Naas)

There are two characters in the setting. They are working in a company called CloudOn. They are in the same department. The first character is a guy named Danny. Danny is the guy who loves Cloud Computing. The second character is a girl named Sophia. Sophia is the one who disapprove Cloud Computing.
 Danny: Ah! Why is our company still not moving to the Cloud?? My job and my life could be so much easier!
 Sophia: (was looking away, now looking at Danny) Don’t you think the cloud is a bit dangerous for our company? I think we are not prepared for that.
 Danny: Nonsense! Cloud Computing is perfect for our company! If we had our data stored on the cloud. We could access the company’s data from anywhere around the globe! It is so convenient! We can move beyond time zone and geographic location issues!
 Sophia: Uhmmm.... yeah... but don’t you think it is risky to store information in the cloud? Well maybe, we are more prone to data loss and leakage?
 Danny: How it is so?
 Sophia: The threat of data compromise increases in the cloud, due to the number of and interactions between risks and challenges which are either unique to cloud, or more dangerous because of the architectural or operational characteristics of the cloud environment.
 Danny: Yeah, but what we could do is:implement strong API access control and encrypt and protect integrity of data in transit.
 Sophia: hmm.. but still Danny, I think we have to wait for the CIO to decide. Dealing with the Cloud is a big decision for this company.

Question 2: \nThe answer is \"True\", because looking at the permissions of an app could reveal that the app is requesting more permissions than it needs, like access to your contacts or any other sensitive data, which could be misused.

Question 3: \nThe answer is "A and B", because if Jake had read reviews, he might have been informed about the malware, or if he had checked the permissions requested by the device he may have noticed that it requested the ability to send text messages.

Over 90% of mobile malware in 2013 was targeted at Android devices, and it continues to be the target of the majority of malware attacks. Because of this, it is important to be cautious in how you use your Android devices in order to keep yourself safe from malware. One of the simplest things that can be done to avoid malware is to check the reviews for any app before downloading, as sometimes a review will contain information about malware. Users should also avoid installing apps from untrusted sources, as there is no guarantee what the untrusted app will contain. Other things that can be done are using a password on the lock screen, using trusted antivirus and anti-malware apps (such as the built in Google app scanner on Android), encrypting your device, updating your device, and carefully reading the permissions screen when installing an application. On top of malware, there are other types of potentially undesirable apps, such as apps with spyware and apps that abuse permissions. Once again, users should check reviews, as they sometimes contain reports about undesirable features of an app, as well as paying careful attention to the requested permissions of an app before downloading. Failing to protect your mobile device can lead to many undesirable and potentially costly consequences. One recent example was a set of apps that used the phones of users to mine for bitcoins (a cryptocurrency). This resulted in the users battery draining extremely fast. Other examples of malware or unwanted apps are apps that access data on the phone without the users permission, apps with deceptive ads, and apps that attempt to use phishing to gain user credentials.

Jake had been hearing a lot from his friends about an Android game called Flappy Bird, and finally decided to give it a try. Going onto the app store, he searched for the game but was surprised to find that there were a many different results with the same name. Selecting one at random, he skipped through the permissions screen and quickly downloaded the game. Hours later, a Jake threw his phone down in frustration after failing to beat his high score of 4. Not realizing that he had exposed his phone to malware, he soon forgot about Flappy Bird, but left it installed on his phone. Upon receiving his phone bill at the end of the month, he was baffled to find that he had a variety of charges due to text messages to “premium” numbers that he didn\'t recall making. When he searched for an answer to why he had been charged for texts he never sent, he found that the Flappy Bird app he had downloaded was a fake, and actually had malware that used its permissions to send the texts in order to rack up charges.

If you have gotten this far in SecurEd, you have learned about Vulnerabilities, Threats, and Attacks. The quiz at the end of this section will present to you some specific Threats and Attacks, so we will define them here for your knowledge. The following are some types of Threats that are important to know. Sabotage/Vandalism is the destruction of systems or information. Technological Software Failure would include things like bugs, code problems, and unknown loopholes. Technological Obsolescence means antiquated or outdated technologies. Technological Hardware Failure refers to equipment failure, like a faulty component or wire. The following attacks are important to know as well. A Software Attack is something like a virus or Trojan. Phishing is defined as an attempt to gain personal or financial information from an individual, usually by posing as a legitimate entity. Spoofing is a technique used to gain unauthorized access; an intruder assumes a trusted IP address in this attack. A sniffer is a program or device that monitors data traveling over a network. Sniffers can be used for both legitimate purposes and for stealing information from a network. Pharming is the redirection of legitimate Web traffic to an illegitimate site for the purpose of obtaining private information. We will also see the importance of Technological Obsolescence in the story, involving a router that uses Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) encryption. WEP encryption has been proven to be insecure due to the nature of its key usage. An article describing breaking WEP encryption in 60 seconds can be found at http://eprint.iacr.org/2007/120.pdf. WEP encryption has been superseded by Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA), a secure encryption scheme, although WEP is still supported because many devices still have hardware only for WEP encryption, as we see in the story.

Alison attends college in her home state, twenty minutes from her parents’ house. During the summer, she was back at home visiting her parents for a week, and still had the WiFi password stored in her phone. She was thinking of buying a gift for her mother, a gardening enthusiast, before leaving for college. She wanted to get something seasonal that her mother would enjoy, and knowing that they both liked pumpkin pie, decided to buy her some pumpkin seeds to plant in the garden. There was one router and one desktop computer in the house that hadn’t been used very much by her slightly computer-illiterate parents, but it still functioned and provided Internet access. The router was fairly outdated, and still offered WEP encryption, an encryption scheme that has been proven to be insecure but is still used in out-of-date machines that haven’t been replaced. Alison, wanting to be discrete, decided to make the seed purchase on her phone so that she wouldn’t get walked in on by her mother and have the surprise ruined. She opened up the website of a gardening store and tapped through the checkout process, paid with her debit card, and chose to deliver the seeds to her house so she could gift wrap them before she left for college. Meanwhile, at her neighbor’s house, a group of highly computer-literate boys were having a sleepover. One of the boys’ fathers worked as a freelance mobile developer, and had shown him how sniffers work so that he would be informed about potential dangers with today’s new technology. This boy was showing off an advanced decrypting sniffer that his dad had installed on his phone, and they decided to try it out. They were able to see the WiFi traffic of all houses surrounding theirs, as the houses in this neighborhood were quite close together, and some were duplexes. The sniffer showed the boys the binary stream of the bits for each router, but most houses had modern encryption schemes and the sniffer didn’t know how to decrypt them. One of the traffic streams was able to be decrypted by the sniffer, and the boys were shocked to find the website, debit card number, address, and other information that Alison was entering into her phone over her insecure WEP encryption connection.
